data.title: Refactored PowerShell language definitions
data.body:
This is a total refactoring of the language definitions (.tmlanguage) file.

Notable changes:
- General clean-up (moved most of the matching rules to the repository, logically grouped rules etc.)
- Supports the Stop Parsing operator
- Added some illegal scopes (bad variable names and space after backtick ++)
- Added comments where I felt it was needed
- Much better command highlighting, with highlighting of parameters
- Workaround for highlighting the reserved word 'default' in switch-blocks (Will only highlight the word inside scriptblocks, so will also highlight in `{default}`
- Fixed highlighting of comment based help keywords
- More consequent highlighting of numerical constants
- Changed some scope names
- Better type highlighting
- Highlighting of keywords in classes
- Added highlighting of built-in aliases and executable files (.ps1, .exe etc)
- Added highlighting of some missing operators
- Better highlighting of properties/members

Compare: [Old](https://github-lightshow.herokuapp.com/?utf8=%E2%9C%93&scope=from-url&grammar_url=https%3A%2F%2Fraw.githubusercontent.com%2FMicrosoft%2Fvscode%2Fmaster%2Fextensions%2Fpowershell%2Fsyntaxes%2FPowershellSyntax.tmLanguage&grammar_text=&code_source=from-url&code_url=https%3A%2F%2Fraw.githubusercontent.com%2Fgravejester%2FEditorSyntax%2FRefactoring%2Fexamples%2FTheBigTestFile.ps1&code=) vs [New](https://github-lightshow.herokuapp.com/?utf8=%E2%9C%93&scope=from-url&grammar_url=https%3A%2F%2Fraw.githubusercontent.com%2FPowerShell%2FEditorSyntax%2Fmaster%2FPowerShellSyntax.tmLanguage&grammar_text=&code_source=from-url&code_url=https%3A%2F%2Fraw.githubusercontent.com%2Fgravejester%2FEditorSyntax%2FRefactoring%2Fexamples%2FTheBigTestFile.ps1&code=)

@daviwil

data.title: Support file watching on Windows < .NET Framework 4.5

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hi,

Code recently added a dependency on .NET Framework 4.5 on Windows 7 (I believe to address issue #9). .NET Framework 4.5 is an optional update on Windows 7. However, I am using Code on my work PC and do not have admin rights, so am unable to install this. Code still seems to function largely OK (except for the automatic file update issue related to #9), but I get a repeated warning to install the .NET framework which gets old pretty fast.

Any chance of adding an option to disable this warning for those of us using Code on Windows 7 with no admin rights to update the .NET framework?

Thanks for a great product! 
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Windows 7 32-bit

data.title: Remove "Last checked" on update menu item
Monaco API build error: EditorWorkerClient not exported
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Latest from master

Steps to repro: 

```
# Build VSCode once to get a new `out` folder
./node_modules/.bin/gulp compile

# This generates a new `src/vs/monaco.d.ts`
node ./build/monaco/api

# This generates the `out-monaco-editor-core` folder which is for npm publishing
./node_modules/.bin/gulp editor-distro
```

Errors: 

```
[14:09:20] [check semantics] C:/REPOS/monaco/vscode/node_modules/typescript/lib/lib.d.ts
[14:09:20] [tsb] time: 35858ms mem: 836MB Δ788
*** Error: C:/REPOS/monaco/vscode/src/vs/monaco.d.ts(660,45): Cannot find name 'EditorWorkerClient'.
*** Finished with 1 errors.
```

refs https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7290 :rose:

data.title: An API to get a range of visible positions in the editor
data.body:
It would be useful for extension developers to get a range of visible positions (or lines) in the editor.

This would be useful when the extension is dealing with the visual aspect of the VSCode since the extension does not need to update the visual on invisible area.

For example, [Guides](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=spywhere.guides) needs to update its indentation guide lines but this has impact the extension performance (https://github.com/spywhere/vscode-guides/issues/6) due to a calculation on whole file which cause the lag on the VSCode. With this API, Guides can now update only visible area, reduce the necessity of update the invisible area which can improve the performance a lot.

data.title: [quick fix] ⌘. twice to quickly apply the quick fix

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Would be nice if instead of pressing `⌘.` then `Enter` to apply the quick fix, you could just press `⌘.` two times in a row. Then, pressing it again could move the cursor to the next (quick fixable) issue, so you could repeatedly fix everything by just pressing `⌘.` several times in a row.

data.title: VS Code crash and locks guest VM - running on linux through virtualbox
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.0
- OS Version: both linux mint 17.3 and centos 7

I believe this is related to issue #5126. 

This is an issue that I have all the time when, running a linux vm under virtualbox -- since vbox additions 5.0.20 (although I believe on 5.0.18 as well).

While I suspect that it's upstream, I was hoping to find a way to turn off hardware acceleration on VS Code - which is why I was out here looking for a related issue. 

Is there a switch or config option to turn off hardware acceleration for VS Code and that would let Code run? Would this be something that could be added?

For me, on a virtualbox linux vm, both the Chrome browser and VS Code lock completely and only runs correctly when either...
1) I turn off 3D display acceleration for the the whole guest vm in the settings, then both run OK, or...
2) I run virtualbox guest additions 5.0.16 or earlier, then both run OK
3) I can turn off hardware acceleration for the Chrome browser, in Chrome settings, then Chrome browser runs OK, even with the 3D accel on for the rest of the client vm - which is why I was looking for an option to turn it off in VS Code

In all cases, the vbox host is windows 10 pro

Hope that makes sense.

thanks,
David

data.title: Paste in 64bit PowerShell Terminal duplicates text pasted.
support for long / asynchronous call stacks in Node.js debugger
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `code --version` -> 1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6 Beta (15G12a)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. start with this code
   
   ``` js
   setTimeout(() => {
     Promise.resolve()
       .then(() => {
         throw new Error('catch me!')
       })  
   })
   ```
2. set a breakpoint on the `throw`, and debug in VSCode (as a Node.js project)
   
   ![screen shot 2016-06-10 at 09 19 15](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/479816/15949712/e93ec410-2eec-11e6-9225-e2ed32b36732.png)
   - observe that the Call Stack lists just a single frame.
3. debug this in Chrome, with DevTools, with "Async" checked (near the Call Stack and Breakpoints lists)
   
   ![screen shot 2016-06-10 at 09 19 05](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/479816/15949755/3bf4c98e-2eed-11e6-8924-faa2339c6f0a.png)
   - observe that the Call Stack lists multiple asynchronous frames

Whilst researching this, I did come across a similar feature request for node-inspector:
- https://github.com/node-inspector/node-inspector/issues/340

Being able to easily trace the asynchronous flow leading up to an exception (or a breakpoint) is an incredibly powerful tool in the JavaScript developer's arsenal.

It is interesting to note that this is not on by default in Chrome DevTools. Perhaps having this on all the time has considerable performance ramifications? I've had "Async" checked ever since it was announced, but I can imagine a release that turns this on by default could be met with developer confusion / frustration.

Would following Chrome's lead here and just providing a checkbox (or a flag in the debug configuration JSON) be the best initial approach?

data.title: Group level commands when tabs are disabled

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
_From UX Meeting: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7338, topic "Update on separating editor and group actions"_
## No Tabs: Group Level Commands

As a part of the work to support tabs, we made some assumptions about the need for managing stacks of editors when tabs are **not** enabled. We believed that users would want the following:
- A group level affordance that indicates when there are multiple editors open in a group (when clicked it shows these open editors).
- A group level overflow button with the following items:
  - “Close All” open editors in a group at once, thus closing the group when empty editors are not enabled.
  - “Move Left” / “Move Right” the group (same result as dragging a group).

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1487073/15947974/2eef5dca-2e53-11e6-819a-de3fb1b57d28.png)

After dogfooding with the [Insiders Release](https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders) we think it’s possible these UI elements are actually not needed:
- The Open Editors area in the explorer already indicates when multiple editors are open in a group and what they are.
- Closing all editors is possible from Open Editors
- Moving groups left and right is already possible through dragging the editor or in Open Editors, although this needs to be accessible

Furthermore, it is visually "noisy" to have these group-level commands when tabs are not enabled.  The extra buttons increase the complexity, and the lighter gray background that separates the group-level commands from the editor commands is heavy and attention-grabbing.

Finally, corner cases exist where you could have two overflow menus, one for local commands and one for group-level commands.  This is confusing and undesirable.

![doubleoverflow](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1487073/15948080/b0eda91c-2e53-11e6-84d6-4f174b80a86f.jpeg)
### Conclusion

We decided that it would be best to revert these changes and remove the group-level commands to eliminate duplicate functionality and keep the current ("no tabs") model intact for the "tabs disabled" scenario.

data.title: Installation of extension only works if home-data-dir already exists
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu LTS 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Don't open vscode (at least don't install an extension via vscode-gui)
2. from console: code --install-extension eg2.tslint
3. you get an error - no such file or directory: /home/vagrant/.vscode/extensions

Temporary fix for me (I'm using this in vagrant):
mkdir -p /home/vagrant/.vscode/extensions
code --install-extension eg2.tslint

So I do a mkdir beforehand, so the install won't fail.

Thanks!

data.title: Add multiple terminals
[coffeescript] syntax coloring support for ES6
data.body:
Standard `tmLanguage` syntax definitions don't support ES6 syntax, e.g. keyword `yield`, classes `ArrayBuffer` and `Symbol`, etc.

For Coffeescript [this](https://github.com/aponxi/sublime-better-coffeescript/blob/master/CoffeeScript.tmLanguage) could be used, as for JS and TS - I have no suggestions, because I don't use those.

data.title: Prefill reported issue body with version and OS when triggered from menu
data.body:
You can set the issue body using the query string https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/new?body=[body] This would be convenient for the team to auto-fill this information when using Help > Report Issues, it would also help reduce an extra round trip if the community leaves out their OS and leave out the version. It will also give us the commit which will be increasingly useful information for insiders towards the end of the month. I can't figure out how to do new lines in the query string is the only issue, `\n`, `
` and `<br>` all seem to not work.

data.title: Reveal in Explorer does not bring the File Explorer window to the foreground

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Right click on a file in the files list, choose "Reveal in Explorer"

observe that the explorer window opened does not come to the foreground.

Usually this type of problem us due to not passing the foreground privilege on correct. If COM is used to transport the call from one thread to another use CoAllowSetForegroundWindow() on the COM object that will invoke the API that opens File Explorer.
Also verify you are using SHOpenFolderAndSelectItems API to open the window and select the file.
